text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Retailer Vendex goes sells its 36 pct stake in department store chain Koninklijke Bijenkorf Beheer (KBB). (p1)
- Brewer Heineken in race to buy Volvo's majority stake in Swedish brewer Pripps-Ringnes. (p1)
- Public prosecutor demands prison sentences for directors of defunct stockbroker Nusse Brink. (p1)
- Publisher Bosch & Keuning seeks buyer for its printing division. (p3)
- Dutch credit insurer NCM signs cooperation agreement with Japanese rival EID/Miti. (p3)
- Major private shareholder in biotechnology firm Artu Biologicals reduces his stake from 47 pct to 30 pct. (p11)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- John Leighton of London's National Gallery is appointed director of Amsterdam's Van Gogh Museum. (p1)
- Parliament demands more traffic police. (p1)
- KBB helps Vendex by buying back 500,000 of its own shares. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- Fierce quarrel between Labour and Liberals over increase in excise duties on petrol and tobacco. (p1)
- China lifts ban on imports of Dutch poultry. (p1)
- Cofidential report says projects for expensive apartments and office buildings in Amsterdam's town centre unfeasible, if city sticks to rigid car-parking policy. (p7)
- Food and detergent concern Unilever has no intention of selling off units in order to raise profitability, says Unilever NV chairman Morris Tabaksblat. (p23)
TROUW
- Bank insurer ING to build 85 million guilder office in Warsaw. (p6)
- D66 member of parliament says Korea's Samsung is still demanding too much money from Dutch government in support of its plans to take over bankrupt plane maker Fokker. (p7)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- Prime Minister Wim Kok writes to French president Jacques Chirac, urging France to lift police and customs checks along its northern border. (p1)
- British D.I.Y. store chain Wickes considers sale of its shops in the Benelux countries. (p11)
-- Amsterdam newsroom +31 20 504 5000, Fax +31 20 504 5040
